definition:
Let $\mathscr{H}$ and $\mathscr{K}$ be Hilbert spaces. An operator
$W \in L(\mathscr{H}, \mathscr{K})$ is called a *partial isometry* if
$W$ is an isometry on $M = (\ker W)^{\perp}$. We then call
$M = (\ker W)^{\perp}$ the *initial space* and $N = WM$ *final space* of
$W$.

We need to show that the above definition is compatible with the general
definition of partial isometry on rings. Indeed we have the following:

$W \in L(\mathscr{H},\mathscr{K})$ is a partial isometry iff $W^* W$ is
a projection from $\mathscr{H}$ to $M$.

We have: $$\begin{aligned}
W & \ \text{partial isometry with initial space} \ M \\
\Leftrightarrow {\langle Wf, Wg \rangle} &= {\langle f, g \rangle} \ \forall \ f,g \in M \\
\Leftrightarrow {\langle W^* W f, g \rangle} &= {\langle f, g \rangle} \ \forall \ f \in M, g \in \mathscr{H} \\
\Leftrightarrow W^* W f &= f, f \in M \\
\text{and} \ W^* W f &= 0, f \in M^{\perp} = \ker W\end{aligned}$$

If $W \in L(\mathscr{H}, \mathscr{K})$ is a partial isometry with
initial space $M$ and final space $N$ we have: $$\begin{aligned}
W^* (Wf) &= f \ \forall \ f \in M \\
\ker W^* &= ({\mathrm{ran}}W)^{\perp} = N^{\perp}\end{aligned}$$

Thus $N$ is the initial space and $M$ the final space of $W^*$.
